sbdata.sbtitle: Replacement of the no longer manufactured component.
Introduction of other source of pressure sensor memories (Amdt.B).
Improvement of the P90−3 pressure sensor.

prcitem.para: This document is prepared as recommended by ATA Specification 2100. It describes the operation and technical characteristics of the equipment and gives the instructions for its maintenance.
The identification is given by the permanent and modifiable bar code and amendment labels installed on the lateral face of the equipment.
The permanent bar code label () gives this information:

unlitem.para: MFR: Manufacturer code in alphanumeric and bar code form
DMF: Date of final factory inspection (month and year) in numeric and bar code form
SER: Basic part number and serial number in alphanumeric and bar code form.

prcitem.para: The modifiable bar code label () () gives this information:

unlitem.para: PNR: Equipment Part Number in alphanumeric and bar code form

entry.para: Model of equipment in the type

prcitem.para: Change to the equipment are shown as follows:
For important changes (called "Modifications"), the equipment version or the hardware and/or software modification state is increased by one increment: A becomes B, 01 becomes 02 and so on.
For less important changes (called "Amendments") which have no effect on the interchangeability of the equipment, the letter related the amendment is put on the amendment label ().

caution.para: THE EQUIPMENT CONTAINS ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE SENSITIVE (ESDS) DEVICES. YOU MUST BE VERY CAREFUL WITH THESE DEVICES. UNWANTED VOLTAGES (STATIC OR INDUCED VOLTAGES, LEAK VOLTAGES, ETC.) BETWEEN THE INPUT AND OUTPUT TERMINALS OF ESDS DEVICES CAN EASILY CAUSE DAMAGE TO THEM. TO KEEP THE RISK OF FAILURE TO A MINIMUM:

unlitem.para: NEVER LET THE TERMINALS OF AN ESDS DEVICE STAY IN OPEN CIRCUIT.
OBEY THE SPECIAL PRECAUTIONS GIVEN IN THE STANDARD PRACTICES MANUAL (ATA No. 22−09−04) FOR ALL OPERATIONS ON ESDS DEVICES AND THEIR BOARDS.

prcitem.para: One label on the rear face () gives a warning that the equipment contains ESDS devices.
One TSO/QAC label on the lateral face () gives the reference of the QAC, TSO and JTSO standards, the weight of the equipment, and the range of the ALT and IAS functions of the equipment.

The tables show the subassemblies installed in the equipment (Title and Part Number), the changes made to the equipment (Modifications and Amendments) with the related subassembly changes, and the equipment designators for the installation of each subassembly in the equipment.
Inertial Measurement Unit:

unlitem.para: The proposed equipment contains a component (Inertial Measurement Unit) which is subject to US export control under the Export Administration regulations , ECCN 7A 994.
They may be exported with a specific export licence to all countries for use in civil aircraft ony, except those subject to anti−terrorism controls or covered under general trade restrictions.
A specific export licence may be requested from US Department of Commerce. Diversion contrary to US law is prohibited.

note.para: For the PRESSURE SENSOR ASSY (A8), the PN E17397AA or E17393BA can be installed

topic.title: Verification of the Procedures in the Manual

prcitem.para: Testing and Fault Isolation: shop verification done by performance NOV 15/00
Disassembly: shop verification done by performance NOV 15/00
Assembly: shop verification done by performance NOV 15/00.
A number of abbreviations are used in the document to make the text and illustrations shorter. These abbreviations and their definitions are given in the table that follows.

defdata.def: Flat Panel Instrument, Flat Panel Interface

prcitem.para: The purpose of the instrument is to give a standby display of the parameters that follow:
Attitude
Standard or baro−corrected altitude, and the related barometric pressure
Indicated airspeed.
In relation to the configuration of the discretes, the instrument can also display these parameters:
ILS deviation
Indicated Mach number
Barometric pressure in hPa and/or in.Hg
Altitude corrected as a function of a Static Source Error Correction (SSEC) law
VMO information
Skid/Slip information
The discretes also permit the adaptation of the instrument to the panel tilt angle.
for the general architecture of the instrument.
Physical Data
Overall dimensions: .
Weight: 4.4 lbs (2 kg) +/−2%.
Electrical Data
Power Supply:

unlitem.para: +28VDC (maximum current less than 0.7A in operational mode)
0−28VDC (screen lighting control voltage) (maximum current less than 0.01A) .
0−5VAC/400Hz (pushbutton lighting control voltage) (maximum current less than 0.01A) .

prcitem.para: Lightning strike/EMI protection: The RS422 input and output, one output discrete and three mode configuration discretes have EMI protection but not lightning strike protection. All the other inputs and outputs have EMI protection and lightning strike protection.
Input/Output Summary
Inputs

note.para: The 16 discretes include seven optional function coding discretes.

prcitem.para: Outputs
Pneumatic Data
The instrument has two pressure unions: J2 for pitot pressure and J3 for static pressure.
Leakage: for a pressure of 500 hPa in the pneumatic circuits, the leakage is not more than 1.7 hPa.
for a general view of the instrument.
and the related legend for the elements on the front face of the instrument.

entry.para: "STD" pushbutton for set Baro_STD or to Baro_Corrected.
"BARO"’ rotary knob is used to adjust the barometric pressure.
"CAGE" pushbutton to reset the horizon (attitude) function to the zero.

prcitem.para: and the related legend for the parts and subassemblies of the instrument.

entry.para: Rear face assembly. It includes the rear plate with the pressure unions J2 (pitot) , J3 (static) and the quick disconnects, the Filter Interconnection board A11 and the ESDS label (3).
Control Processor Graphic Display Unit. It is connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by one 125−pin connector.
Programmed Interface board. It is connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by one 125−pin connector.

Optical Assembly (OA). It includes a liquid crystal display (LCD) matrix DS1, the light box that contains three tubes and the CBL board A51. ThTEST REFEXTis assembly is connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by two flex circuits.
Front face assembly. It includes the Front Face board A61, the control pushbuttons and knobs . This assembly is connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by one 30−pin connector.

Pressure sensor assembly. It includes two boards A7 and A8 that are electrically connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by one 12−pin connector. The boards are mechanically connected to the pressure unions J2 and J3 by hoses attached by ties.

Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU). It contains three single−axis rate sensors and their temperature probes, three acceleration sensors and their temperature probes, one IMU board and one mechanical structure. This assembly is connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by one 36−pin connector.
Filter Interconnection board. It includes the 41−pin external connector J1 and is connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by two 23−pin strip connectors.
Power supply unit. It is connected to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 by one 30−pin connector.
Programmed Motherboard. It makes the interconnection between all the subassemblies of the instrument.

prcitem.para: Functions
The instrument has four principal modes:
OPER mode: operational mode used on aircraft
SIMU: mode used during simulation
MAINT: mode used for line maintenance
DWNLD: mode used for software downloading.
These modes are accessible after power−up, in relation to the combination of the three configuration discretes E1 to E3 ().
From the OPER mode, it is possible to get access to the CAGING function : reset of the attitude function (ATT).

At power−up, INIT phase () does the initialization of the instrument before the MAINT, SIMU and OPER modes. The initialization procedure is run before the instrument becomes operational. This procedure includes the actions that follow:

unlitem.para: The startup of the time bases and hour meter
Validation of the pin programming configuration

prcitem.para: After a power−down of the +28V supply voltage for more than 50ms, the LOW POWER degraded mode saves the instrument status before it changes to OFF mode.
If an error occurs that does not prevent operation, the instrument changes to ERROR submode.
If an error occurs that prevents operation, the instrument changes to FAIL mode.
OFF mode is active after a power−down of the instrument.
Modes
OPER ( and )
After INIT mode and in relation to the three configuration discretes, the instrument calculates and displays the data that follow:

unlitem.para: Standard or baro−corTEST REFEXTrected altitude (selection by the BARO rotary knob)
Sideslip indication (filtered lateral acceleration− only for option)

prcitem.para: MAINT Mode ()
This mode is used to do a test of the instrument and to display the faults recorded.
There are six maintenance pages. The change from one page to another is done with the CAGE pushbutton.

This mode is similar to OPER mode but the combination of the configuration discretes is different. The simulated values (sensor data) are received on the ARINC 429 buses No 2 and No 3. The data transmitted are the same as in OPER mode.

The instrument goes into this mode after power−up when the three input mode discretes EI to E3 are in the DWNLD configuration. This mode enables the unit to dialog with the outside systems through the RS422 bus. This bus provides an exchange at a speed of 115.2Kbs.
To exit from DWNLD mode, de−energize the instrument.

sheet.title: NIT Phase and OPER Screen Mode

entry.para: Fixed white scale with roll graduations at 10−degree intervals between −30 and +30 degrees and at −45, +45, −60 and +60 degrees. The roll angle is shown by a reference triangle.
Fixed white roll triangle with a black background.

Moving pitch scale with graduations at 5−degree intervals between −30 and +30 degrees, at 2.5−degree intervals between −20 and +20 degrees, and at 10−degree intervals from −80 to +80 degrees. At a pitch angle of more than 30 degrees or less than −20 degrees, graduations and characters are replaced by red stripes at +40, +60, +80, −30, −60 and −80 degrees.
For the high pitch values where normally only one color of the tape background is visible, an opposite color area is kept to permit an unambiguous reading of the attitude.

Green diamonds (LOC and G/S). If the ILS data is in the scale range, the diamonds are displayed. If the ILS data is out of the scale range, only a half−diamond is displayed in the out−of−range direction and the scale flashes.
ILS annunciator displayed by green large letters on the background.
The Airspeed data is given by a tape that moves in front of a trapezoidal pointer with a black background.

The moving airspeed tape is graduated at intervals of 5 Knots from 40 to 250 Knots and at intervals of 10 Knots for the higher values. A numerical indication is added to the graduation at 20−Knot intervals.
Fixed airspeed trapezium which contains the airspeed number value which is:
− Green on a klack background when the airspeed or mach NUMBER IS LOWER THAN VMO or MMO,
− White on a klack background in the opposite case.

The VMO is shown by a red tape associated with the Airspeed tape. It comes into view at the top of the window when the related part of the Airspeed tape comes into view. The graduations of the Airspeed tape have priority over the VMO tape.

The digital Mach number is displayed in numerical form: letter M, decimal point and two numerals. The characters are green when the Airspeed or Mach number is lower than VMO or MMO and red in the opposite case.
The altitude is shown as follows:

unlitem.para: A simulated numerical drum that shows the 10,000 ft increments graduated at intervals of 20 ft.
A moving tape graduated at intervals of 100 ft and identified at intervals of 500 ft.
For positive altitudes less than 1000 ft, a black background is set in place of the 10,000 ft and 1000 ft numbers.
For altitudes less than 0 ft, the 10,000 ft number is replaced by a black N on a green background.

entry.para: Every 1,000 ft, characters are highlighted between two lines by a single thick white line.

Digital readout that shows the barometric pressure in hectopascals (hPa) from 745 to 1100 hPa and inches of mercury (in.Hg) from 22 to 32.5 in.Hg. If the standard barometric pressure is selected, the standard pressure value (1013.25 Hpa or 29.92 in.Hg) is displayed in place of the digital readout.
The SSEC annunciator is displayed by black letters on a yellow background.
The indication "CAGE" is shown for 10 seconds after the release of the "CAGE" button. The CAGE function is not operational during INIT mode.

prcitem.para: Failure Modes

This mode is engaged after a power−down of the 28V power supply for more than 50ms. The instrument status is saved and the calculations stay operational. The display is inhibited during the power−down.
FAIL
This submode displays an OUT OF ORDER page with the related failure code ().
LOSS OF SSEC

This mode is engaged when a failure occurs in the airspeed function while the instrument is in a mode which uses the SSEC correction. In this event, the SSEC correctionTEST REFEXT is no longer used to compute altitude, and the SSEC failure flag is displayed. The SSEC failure flag is displayed when Pt information is not received. The instrument operates in degraded altitude mode with Ps information only().

entry.para: A red ATT flag is shown in place of the gyro horizon display if the instrument cannot supply the attitude information for more than 10 seconds. In this case, the airplane symbol is not displayed.
A red ALT flag is shown in place of the altitude scale if the instrument cannot supply the altitude data.
A red IAS flag is shown in place of the airspeed scale if the instrument cannot supply the airspeed data.
A red LOC or G/S flag.
If only one function LOC or G/S is failed, the related pointer and scale are removed and the related flag is displayed (LOC or G/S).
A red ILS flag is shown in place of the ILS annunciator.

If the two functions LOC and G/S are failed, the two pointers and associated scales are removed and the LOC and G/S flags are replaced by the red ILS flag. It has priority over the ILS flag annunciator.
A black SSEC annunciator is shown in place of the Mach Number display.

prcitem.para: Hardware Operation
The instrument receives these types of data:

unlitem.para: Digital data on the ARINC 429 buse (one Low Speed −−>HEADING Bus).
Activation of the ILS, MACH, SKID/SLIP and Baro pressure in in.Hg or hPa
Configuration of the operating mode discretes of the instrument

prcitem.para: After acquisition of the data, the instrument processes them for display on the color LCD screen. The backlighting of the LCD screen is supplied from fluorescent lamps. It is controlled automatically from the dimming control. The screen is a high−resolution active−matrix LCD of the flat panel type.
The instrument supplies these output data:

unlitem.para: Digital data on the ARINC 429 buses (two Low Speed Buses)
Discrete data for the status of the display.

prcitem.para: The instrument is energized from a 28VDC power supply. It also receives a 5VDC supply for external brightness control and +28VDC for the screen lighting.
The RS422 line is used to download software and for the test of the instrument.
Integrated Maintenance Capabilities (not applicable).
Configuration Setting (not applicable).
Illustrated Block Texts ().
The detailed operation of the instrument is given in the Illustrated Block Texts (IBTs). Each IBT has two sheets:

unlitem.para: A "Block Diagram" sheet which shows a schematic representation of the related circuit
A text sheet which gives details about the block diagram.

prcitem.para: Refer to Manual ATA No. 34−22−47A.
The interconnection of the equipment with the external environment is made through one 41−pin connector J1.
The table that follows gives the list of all the pins of the external connector, the generic signal names and types (input and output) and the rTEST REFEXTeal signal names.
The internal interconnection of the instrument is made through a programmed interconnection TB1 ().
Obey the CAUTION and WARNING information when you do work on the boards and assemblies.
The procedures that follow tell the user how to disassemble the unit to the extent necessary for its repair.
Standard Tools, Fixtures and Equipment
Special Tools, Fixtures and Equipment

note.para: The special tools are identified in the text by an alphanumeric code.
Example: ST01

None.
Referenced Information
to identify the parts.

note.para: The first number in brackets is the figure number and the second is the number of the item on the figure.

prcitem.para: to find the cause of a malfunction. Disassemble the unit only to the extent necessary for fault isolation.
Read the history or record card, if there is one, to fTEST REFEXTind possible defective areas which you must look at.
Disassemble the equipment only as much as is necessary to replace the defective parts.
The screws are safetied with red paint (Pa−pa−010) () . This paint can be removed with a cellulose solvent (Ol−so−013) () .
Replace all the sealing rings removed with new sealing rings.
Do the disassembly operations in a clean environment (no dust).
The references to the left and right, front and rear of the equipment are given in relation to its normal test position.
Disconnect the equipment from all power sources before disassembly.
When the equipment contains electrostatic sensitive devices, refer to the Standard Practices Manual ATA number 22−09−04 for the precautions to use.

prcitem.para: The procedures in this section contain instructions to fully clean the component.
It is necessary to clean the component after assembly of the component and before storage or use.
You must do this removing all traces of finTEST REFEXTger marks, oil, grease, dust and dirt.
Do the cleaning procedure in a clean room
Self explanatory.

note.para: Equivalent substitutes can be used for the items that follow.

prcitem.para: Make sure that the indicator is fully assembled.
Disconnect the equipment from all electrical power sources.
Wash your hands before the start of the cleaning procedure.
Optical Parts

caution.para: DO NOT USE MATERIAL SUCH AS TISSUE PAPER WHEN YOU CLEAN THE OPTICAL PARTS OF THE LRU. SUCH MATERIAL can cause damage TO THE LRU.

unlitem.para: For a finger print or recent mark without grease or oil:
Breathe on the stained area and clean with a soft precision wipe.
Soak a precision wipe in Substrate cleaner (Ol−cl−017).
Use a new precision wipe each time to prevent scratches to the optical parts with the collected dust.
Do the same step again until the optical parts are fully clean.
Soak a precision wipe in isopropyl alcohol (Ol−cl−011).
Carefully rub the painted part with a precision wipe.
Clean the structure with a clean precision wipe.
If you cannot get acces to the parts easily, use the silk paint brush.
For traces of grease, finger prints, etc:
Clean the parts with a clean precision wipe soaked in isopropyl alcohol (Ol−cl−011).

caution.para: Do not touch THE pins oF the electrical connectors. If you touch these conductors, electrostatic discharge can cause damage TO THE LRU.

unlitem.para: Clean the electrical connectors with a soft silk paint brush soaked in isopropyl alcohol (Ol−cl−011).

prcitem.para: The procedures in this section give the instructions for a full check of the LRU.

The check is necessary after repair of the LRU and during assembly. You must do this procedure to make sure that the parts of the LRU and its subassemblies are physically correct and show no signs of wear, damage or risk of failure.
The Standard Practices Manual ATA number 22−09−04 gives standard procedures.
The procedures that follow tell the user how to do the inspection/check of the parts in the unit to find if they are serviceable.

note.para: Equivalent substitutes can be used for the items that follow.

prcitem.para: Read the history or record card, if there is one, to find the possible defective areas which you must look at.

note.para: During assembly of SRUs after a repair, you must do one or all of the checks that follow (i.e. inspection of mechanical and optical parts).

unlitem.para: Do a check of the optical parts for scratches, spots and rings.
Make sure that no part of the optical light sensor is damaged and darkened.
Make sure there are no fingermarks, grease spots and other marks.
Make sure that there are no scratches or blistering of the paint.
Use a magnifying glass to examine all the mechanical parts (heatsinks, screws, etc.)
Do a check of all these parts for signs of shocks or burrs.
Do a check of the condition of the captive screw threads.
Do a check of the screw torques.
Make sure that the spring tension washers and the seals do not show signs of cracking or unusual hardness or softness.
Use a magnifying glass to examine the connector parts (pins, terminal strips, etc.).
Make sure that the connectors are correctly connected during SRU installation.
Do a check of the binding for condition and safe attachment.
Make sure that the wires and the harTEST REFEXTnesses do not shows signs of marks or damage.
Do a check of the ribbon cables for broken wires near the soldered connections.
Make sure that the sensors are in the correct positions.
Do a check of the solder joints.

prcitem.para: The standard procedures are included in the Manual ATA No. 22−09−04.
Self explanatory.
Not applicable
Refer to the Manual ATA No. 22−09−04.
Not applicable.
This procedure is for the replacement or modification of the identification and/or amendment labels.
Self explanatory.

note.para: Equivalent substitutes can be used for the items that follow.

prcitem.para: Procedure

note.para: It is not usually necessary to replace the amendment label each time that the amendment label changes (unless the label showns signs of deterioration). The Modifiable Bar Code Label is replaced when the Part Number of the instrument changes.

prcitem.para: Remove the transparent cover from the label.
Clean the related amendment letter or its position carefully with a lintless cloth soaked in isopropyl alcohol (Ol−cl−011).

note.para: Make sure that there is no grease or dust and that all the adhesive compound from the old label is removed.

prcitem.para: Modify the labels as follows:

unlitem.para: On the labels which have letters, use black ink (Pa−in−004) to put a circle round the related amendment letter.
On new labels, make sure that the same amendment letters are shown as on the old label.

prcitem.para: Put a transparent cover on the amendment label.

note.para: It is necessary to replace these labels if they show signs of deterioration. The Modifiable Bar Code Label is also replaced when the Part Number of the instrument changes.

prcitem.para: Make sure that the new label has all the correct indications
With tweezers or a scalpel, remove the old label. Be careful not to damage the support protection.

With a clean, lint−free cloth soaked in isopropyl alcohol (Ol−cl−011), clean the area where the labels is to be attached to eliminate all traces of grease or dust and to remove the remaining traces of adhesive from the position of the old label.
Put the new label in the correct position.
Make sure that it is in position before you apply pressure.
Press lightly to bond the label.

caution.para: USE THE APPLICABLE ELECTROSTATIC−DISCHARGE SAFETY PRECAUTIONS WHEN YOU DO MAINTENANCE ON OR NEAR DEVICES SENSITIVE TO ELECTROSTATIC DISCHARGE. IF YOU DO NOT DO THIS, YOU CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE EQUIPMENT.

prcitem.para: to identify the parts.

note.para: The first number in brackets is the figure number and the second is the number of the item on the figure.

Example: ST01, SP01

Assemble the equipment from the step at which it was disassembled in DISASSEMBLY.
Read the history or record card, if there is one, to find possible defective areas which you must look at.
During this maintenance procedure, use the precautions that follow:

unlitem.para: Use the standard precautions for electrostatic discharges sensitive devices (ESDS).
Disconnect the equipment from all power sources.
Do the assembly operations in a clean room.
Use gloves to touch the optical part.

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Attach the four board guides (1/52TEST REFEXT0) with the eight screws (1/530) and nuts (1/540).

note.para: For the board guides of the pressure sensor assemblies A7 and A8, the slides must be adjacent to the sensor shielding assembly (1/330).

prcitem.para: Torque the nuts (1/540) to 0.2 Nm.
Safety the heads of the screws (1/530) with red paint (Pa−pa−024).

task.title: Assembly of the Sensor Shielding Assembly

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Attach the sensor shielding assembly (1/330) to the structure (1/590) with the two screws (1/340) and washers (1/350).
Torque the screws (1/340) to 0.2 Nm.
Safety the screw heads with red paint (Pa−pa−024).
Apply a drop of varnish (Ad−si−003) to the attachment points of the shielding assembly (1/330) to prevent vibrations.

task.title: Assembly of the Pressure Sensor Assemblies A7 and A8

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.

caution.para: and the associated PARTS LIST FOR THE PART NUMBERS OF A7 AND A8.

prcitem.para: Attach the eight spacers (1/420) with the eight screws (1/430) safetied with locking compound (Ad−cr−008).
Torque the screws (1/430) to 0.4 Nm.
Engage the pressure sensor assemblies A7 and A8 in their housings. Be careful not to cause damage to the hoses.
Attach the pressure sensor assemblies A7 and A8 to the structure with the screws (1/370) safetied with locking compound (Ad−cr−008).
Torque the screws (1/370) to 0.4 Nm.

task.title: Assembly of the Programmed Motherboard TB1

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Cut three ties (MI−mi−025) to a length of 70mm.
Install the three ties (MI−mi−025) in the related holes on the board TB1 to attach the pressure sensor assembies A7 and A8.

note.para: The loops of the ties must be parallel to the length of the board TB1. The knots will be made on the solder side of the board.

prcitem.para: Install the board TB1 and attach it with the screws (1/560) and the washers (1/570) or the screws (1/560) (only for C16221FA.. Amdt A). Do not tighten the screws fully.
Install the Motherboard hold tool (ST12) on the programmed motherboard TB1 to attach the pressure sensor assembly A7.

note.para: The Motherboard hold tool (ST12) is used to make the assembly easier.

task.title: Assembly of the Rear Module A1

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Attach the rear module A1 with the two screws (1/450), safetied with locking compound (Ad−cr−008).
Torque the screws (1/450) to 0.4 Nm.
Attach the hoses to the Programmed Motherboard TB1 with the three ties (Mi−mi−025) installed before.
Connect the hoses to their related pressure unions.
Use the ties to attach each hose to the related pressure union.
Attach the two hoses that are above the screw (1/450) to prevent interference during tightening.
Do a visual check to make sure that the hoses are not blocked.
Apply a layer of paste (Lu−gr−012) to the sealing rings (1/490 and 1/510).
Install the quick unions (1/480 and 1/500) and the sealing rings (1/490 and 1/510).
Install the protective caps (1/10).

task.title: Assembly of the Power Supply PS1

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
, Safety Precautions.
Install the board PS1 on the Programmed Motherboard TB1.
Attach the board PS1 with the four screws (1/310) safetied with loctite (Ad−cr−008).
Push down the board PS1 to bring the screws to the bottom of the countersunk holes.
Torque the screws (1/310) to 0.7 Nm.

task.title: Assembly of the Programming Interface Board A3

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.

caution.para: DO NOT APPLY TOO MUCH PRESSURE ON THE BOARD CONNECTORS.

prcitem.para: Engage the board A3 in the board TB1.

task.title: Assembly of the Control Processor Graphic Display Unit A2

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Make sure that the fasteners of the unit A2 are in the correct positions.
Make sure that the flex cable is equipped with adhesive tape (Mi−ta−010).
Install the unit A2 in the thermal slides.
Torque the fasteners to 0.2 Nm with the torque screwdriver and the end−fitting (ST13) to attach the unit A2.
Safety the board guides (1/520) with red paint (Pa−pa−024).

task.title: Assembly of the Initial Measurement Unit A9

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Engage the unit A9 in the board TB1.
Attach the unit A9 to the structure (1/590) with the six screws (1/230) and the two screws (1/240) safetied with Loctite (Ad−cr−008).
Torque the screws (1/230) to 0.4 Nm.
Torque the screws (1/240) to 1.6 Nm.

task.title: Assembly of the Optical Module A5

prcitem.para: Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Make sure that the metallic support is equipped with adhesive tape (Mi−ta−003).
Put a piece of cardboard (of the same thickness and length as the flex cable) on the front face A61 to make it possible to hold the flexible cable subsequently.
Bend the flex cables of the matrix to make them straighter.
Put the cradle in the vertical position, with the front of the instrument at the top.
Push on the four corners of the matrix frame at the same time to engage the optical assembly A5.
Apply a drop of bonding compound (Ad−cr−008) to the threads of the four screws (1/200).
Install the four screws (1/200) in the floating nuts but do not tighten them fully.
Turn the instrument to put the cradle at the top.
Put a shim (ST02) under the matrix and push down on the instrument to make sure that the optical assembly A5 is installed at the correct depth.
Torque the screws (1/200) to 0.4 Nm.
Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
,Safety Precautions.
Put the flex cable under the optical module A5.
Install the gasket (1/180) on the board A61 of the front face A6.
Attach the front face A6 to the frame with the four screws (1/160) safetied with bonding compound (Ad−cr−008).
Connect the flex cable of the front face to the connector of the motherboard TB1.
Torque the screws (1/160) to 0.2 Nm.
Self explanatory
to identify the parts.
, Safety Precautions.

caution.para: USE THE SHORT SCREWS TO ATTACH THE BOTTOM COVER AT THE LEVEL OF THE FLEX CABLES ().
THE HOSE THAT DOES NOT HAVE TIES MUST GO ON THE INNER SIDE OF THE INSTRUMENT AND NOT ON THE PROGRAMMING MOTHERBOARD TB1.

prcitem.para: Remove the special hold tool (ST12).
Cut two adhesive foams (Mi−mi−062) to a length of 110mm and then remove the protection paper.
Bond the two foams to the upper cover ().

note.para: The installation of the adhesive foams (Mi−mi−062) can be made easier through the use of the adjustment fixture (ST07).

prcitem.para: Attach the covers (1/120) with the screws (1/130) (in the correct positions) and safety them with bonding compound (Ad−cr−008).
Torque the screws (1/130) to 0.4 Nm.
Apply a bead of mastic (Ad−si−011) between the inertial measurement unit A9 and the front face A6 to prevent leakage of light.
Remove the unwanted mastic and let the mastic cure at ambient room temperature.
Do the downloading procedure ().
This pageblock includes the table of tightening torques.

pgblk.title: SPECIAL TOOLS, FIXTURES, EQUIPMENT AND CONSUMABLES

prcitem.para: This section gives the special tools, fixtures, equipment and consumables that are necessary for operations on the equipment (with their recommended suppliers).

note.para: You can use alternative equipment from other suppliers if they have equivalent properties.
The meaning of the numbers in the USE column are as follows:
1: TESTING 3: DISASSEMBLY 4: CLEANING 5: CHECK 6: REPAIR 7: ASSEMBLY 8: SPECIAL PROCEDURES
You can use alternative equipment from other suppliers if they have equivalent properties.

entry.para: Microsoft Windows NT version 4.0, Service Pack 3 or later and one 115200 bauds RS232 port
One RS232 cable to connect the PC to the instrument

note.para: The meanings of the numbers in the USE column are as follows:
1: TESTING 3: DISASSEMBLY 4: CLEANING 5: CHECK 6: REPAIR 7: ASSEMBLY 8: SPECIAL PROCEDURES
You can use alternative consumables from other suppliers if they have equivalent properties.

entry.para: (Refer to STANDARD PRACTICES Manual ATA No, 22−09−04)

note.para: The meaning of the numbers in the USE column are as follows:
1: TESTING 3: DISASSEMBLY 4: CLEANING 5: CHECK 6: REPAIR 7: ASSEMBLY 9: STORAGE

prcitem.para: The procedures in this pageblock give the instructions for the downloading of the operational software in the instrument, loading software programed motherboard TB1, loading software. The downloading procedure is done through the rear connector of the instrument on the RS422 lines.
Tools, Fixtures and Equipment

unlitem.para: One personal computer (PC) with Microsoft Windows NT version 4.0, Service Pack 3 or later and one 115200 bauds RS232 port with the conversion board RS232/RS422.
One RS232 cable to connect the PC to the instrument.
One downloading software diskette for instrument C16221FA01 F1404303 (ST17).

prcitem.para: Consumables:
Referenced Information:

unlitem.para: to identify the test setup and display.

prcitem.para: Self explanatory

unlitem.para: One personal computer (PC) with Microsoft Windows NT version 4.0, Service Pack 3 or later and one 115200 bauds RS232 port.
One RS232 cable to connect the PC to the adapter box.

prcitem.para: to identify the test setup and Shortcut Icon on Windows Desktop.
,Safety Precautions.
Set the switches connected to inputs “X", "h" and “a” of the instument to the ground position.
Connect the RS422 line of the PC to the inputs "L", "K", "J" and “H” of the instument.
Connect the 28VDC power supply to the inputs “D"(+), "H"(−) of the instument with the double swich in the open position.
Close the double switch to energize the instrument.
Program Setup

note.para: The download program is supplied on diskettes. It is necessary to have "administrator rights" to install the program on the PC.

prcitem.para: Install the diskette 1 in the drive of the PC.
Select "run..." in the "Start" menu.
Enter "’a:/setup" in the dialog box and click on "OK" to start the setup procedure.
Obey the instructions shown on the screen.

note.para: At the end of the downloading procedure, all the files of the program are copied on the hard disk and a shortcut icon is displayed on the Windows desktop ()

prcitem.para: Click on this icon to start the downloading procedure.

note.para: The user can change the parameters that follow:

prcitem.para: The name of the executable file for the downloading program is TELE_FPI_2ND_RS.EXE.
The command line used to run the downloading program is as follows, and has five variable parameters (%1, %2, %3, %4 and %5):
The variable parameters are as follows:
%1: language of the user interface. This parameter is mandatory and the possible values are as follows:
%2: name of the instrument. This parameter is mandatory and the possible values are as follows:

unlitem.para: ICS for an integrated electronic standby instrument
EEI for an electronic engine indicator
EFI for an electronic flight indicator.

prcitem.para: %3: name of the serial communication port. This parameter is mandatory and the possible values are as follows:

unlitem.para: COM1 for the serial port COM1
COMX for the serial port COMX (X is the number of a valid serial port on the PC)
*** for another serial port (*** is the name of the port).

prcitem.para: %4: operating mode. This parameter is optional and includes two modes and two submodes:

unlitem.para: Free mode: the user can select each file to be downloaded into the instrument.
Locked mode: the files are selected by the program in relation to the part number of the instrument.
Locked maintenance submode: the user enters the part number in a dialog box.
Locked shop−floor submode: the part number is supplied in the fifth parameter of the command line.
The possible values for the parameter %4 are given in Table follows ().

entry.para: loocked shop−floor mode C16XXXXX is the instrument Part Number

prcitem.para: %5: serial number of the instrument to be downloaded. This parameter is optional and has the form that follows:

unlitem.para: XX: This is the serial number of the instrument and is only valid if the parameter %4 is C16XXXXX.

prcitem.para: The procedure to change the program parameters is as follows:
Move the cursor to the shortcut icon.
Click on the left button of the mouse and select "Properties" in the scroll menu.
Select the "Shortcut" tabsheet.
Enter the new parameter in the "Target" box after the name of the executable file. For example: C:Program Files/Telechargement/TELE_FPI−2ND−RS.exe GB_ICS_COM1.
Click on "OK" to confirm the changes.
For each new instrument part number (PN), it is necessary to copy the related files on the hard disk.

note.para: The files are supplied by Thales on validated diskettes.

prcitem.para: The procedure to copy the files is as follows:
Launch the program using the shortcut “TELE_FPI_2......”.
Click on the "New PN" button.
In response to the prompt shown on the screen, install the diskette No. 1 that contains the file related to the new PN.
In response to the prompt shown on the screen, install the diskette No. 2 that contains the file related to the new PN.
for thecorrespondance between the part numbers of the disks No.1 and No.2 and instrument.

table.title: Cross Reference Disk and Instrument Part Numbers

prcitem.para: When the copy of all the files is completed, it is possible to download the new instrument.

note.para: The program must be used in Locked Maintenance Mode.

prcitem.para: Launch the program using the short cut “TELE_FPI_2.....”, the “instrument selection page” opens up.
Select the new Part Number in the scrolling list.
Type in the instrument Serial Number.
Click on "OK" to validate, the main window “ Downloading Interface for IESI ” opens up.
Click on the "start" button to initiate the downloading process.
During the downloading do a check of the following message in the box "execution message":
After the downloading of all memory areas the message in the box “execution message “ must be: “ DOWNLOADING SUCCESFULLY COMPLETED “.
Click on the tab “Checksum test “, click on “start “ and do a check of the CHECKSUM in the table “ Read checksum“. The correct CHECKSUM is:

table.title: Cross Checksums and Instrument Part Numbers

prcitem.para: The procedure in this pageblock contains instructions for storage and transportation of the equipment.
The special containers prevent damage to the equipment during transport and are used by Thales Avionics for the initial delivery of the equipment.
Self explanatory.
Standard Tools, Fixtures and Equipment
Special Tools, Fixtures and Equipment
None.
Consumables
Plastic film (Mi−mi−064).
Referenced Information
Clean the equipment before the storage ().
Do a visual check of the equipment before the storage ().
Put a protection plastic cap on the electrical connector.
Put a protection plastic cap on the pressure unions.
Put a protective film on the front face.
Put the equipment in a static shielding bag with a silica gel bag.
Fold the end of the bag on the equipment.
Put all items in the container.
Put the identification labels on the component and on the outside of the container. Make sure that:

unlitem.para: The identification label has all the related data of the equipment.
You can read the labels easily.

prcitem.para: Close the container.

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT THERE IS NOT TOO MUCH WEIGHT ON THE CONTAINER, IF YOU USE THE STACK STORAGE METHOD. TOO MUCH WEIGHT ON THE CONTAINER CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE COMPONENT.
DO NOT KEEP THE CONTAINER NEAR FLUIDS THAT CAN CAUSE CORROSION OR DAMAGE, AND DONOT KEEP NEAR SOURCES THAT MAKE HEAT OR OZONE.

prcitem.para: Keep the container in a clean, dry room with a good supply of air.
Keep the temperature of the room between −15 degrees C (+5 degrees F) and +50 degrees C (122 degrees F).
Keep the relative humidity less than 85 per cent.
Put the container where you can easily read the identification label.
No special transport precautions are necessary if the packing of the equipment is done correctly.
The instrument contains sensitive hardware such as the rate sensors, LCDs, accelerometers and PSM. It is necessary to prevent shocks to the instrument during handling.
This ILLUSTRATED PARTS LIST (IPL) is prepared to ATA Specification 100. It is divided as follows:

The IPL contains a list of all the components used in the equipment. Its function is to help the procurement of parts and subassemblies. The parts given in the IPL must be procured by the Part Numbers and from the manufacturers given in the Parts List. If not, the warranty can be cancelled.
It is possible to identify parts as follows:
Find the related Part Number in the Numerical Index (alpha and num). The columns to the right give the figure and item number of the part in the Detailed Parts List.

prcitem.title: From the Equipment Designator (for electronic components)

prcitem.para: Find the equipment designator of the component on the Electrical Diagram. Then refer to the EDI to find:

unlitem.para: The figure and item number of the component in the Detailed Parts List.

In some cases, there is an individual EDI for each PCB. In this case, the EDI has a GEO LOC column which shows the geographical location of the component on the figure (in relation to terminal 1 of the component).

prcitem.title: If the Part Number or Equipment Designator of the Part are not known

prcitem.para: Look for the figure which shows the part and its item number. Then refer to the Detailed Parts List to find its Part Number.

topic.title: How to use the Detailed Parts List

prcitem.para: The Detailed Parts List contains one or more figures which show the main assemblies of the equipment. Details of the parts are given on the opposite and subsequent pages.
The list is divided into these columns:

unlitem.para: 1st column: Figure Item − Figure and Item number
2nd column: Part Number − Manufacturer"s Part Number
6th column: Units per assy − Quantity for the next higher assembly.

prcitem.para: Details of the columns:

The figure number is given on the first line at the top of each page. Each item in the parts list which has a part number also has an item number. If there is a dash in front of an item number, the item is not shown on the figure. A letter before the item number refers to the figure which shows a variant of the related part. A letter after the item number identifies a variant of the part.

Each assembly, subassembly and detail part has a manufacturer"s Part Number (if it is shown on the figures or not). If the Part Number has more than 15 characters, the data in this column is given for identification only. The full manufacturer"s Part Number is given in the NOMENCLATURE column, after the indication "ORDER OVERLGTH MPN...". It is followed by the FSCM (Federal Supply Code for Manufacturer).
This column is for airline use.

The NOMENCLATURE column gives the names of the assemblies and parts. The indication "ATTACHING PARTS" shows the parts which attach an assembly or part. These attaching parts are given directly below the assembly or part they attach. The next line has three asterisks, the first of which is directly below the item which is attached.

A Vendor Code is given for all the items which do not have a prime manufacturer"s Part Number. This Vendor Code is given at the right of the NOMENCLATURE column. The addresses and codes of Vendors are given in the VENDOR CODE LIST. Optional Part Numbers and Vendors are given in the OPTIONAL PART NUMBER CATALOG, ATA No 22−09−12 or in the OPTIONAL PARTS LIST in the IPL. Please note that only the manufacturers who appear in the OPNC or OPL have been accepted as a result of the equipment qualification test, and should therefore be used.

If a part can come from a range of possible parts, the indication "SEL FROM" is given below the part. The indication "ESDS" is given in the NOMENCLATURE column for electronic components which are sensitive to electrostatic discharges.
The Effectivity Code is a letter which shows the interchangeability of the parts on a figure, as shown below:

unlitem.para: The detail part with item number 10A can only be installed in the unit with item number 1A.
The detail part with item number 10B can be installed in units 1A, 1B and 1C.
The detail part with item number 10C can only be installed in unit 1D.
The subassembly with item number 20A can only be installed in unit 1A.
The subassembly with item number 20B can be installed in units 1A, 1B and 1C.
The subassemblies with item numbers 20C and 20D and their attaching parts 30A can be installed in all the units with item number 1. Thus, they do not have an effectivity code.
The detail part with item number 40A can only be installed in the subassembly with item number 20A.
The detail part with item number 40B can be installed in subassemblies 20A, and 20B.
The detail part with item number 40C can be installed in subassemblies 20A, 20B and 20C.
The detail part with item number 40D can only be installed in subassembly 20D.

prcitem.para: The UNITS PER ASSY column shows the number of parts necessary for the next higher assembly. For some assemblies or parts, the number is replaced by the letters RF (for Reference) and AR (As Required).

topic.title: Abbreviations used in the Detailed Parts List

vendata.mad: THALES AVIONICS1 AVENUE CARNOT 91883 MASSY CEDEX FRANCE
